timeline.message: Add comments, javadoc, remove unused code
Send serviced from cache to BrokerResult
Add validation for telemetry header size and sanitize

timeline.bodyText: nit : use StringBuilder.append() for readability and add a constant for delimiter "|"
timeline.author: kreedula

replies.bodyText: Addressed
replies.author: shahzaibj

timeline.author: kreedula

replies.bodyText: Addressed
replies.author: shahzaibj

timeline.bodyText: nit: constant for the data limit value
timeline.author: kreedula

replies.bodyText: Addressed
replies.author: shahzaibj

timeline.bodyText: Should we indicate the server somehow  that we are not sending the data due to size restrictions. i.e. just for us to be aware that this data could be skewed?
timeline.author: kreedula

replies.bodyText: Such a field is not currently part of the schema. I can add something to the platform telemetry for Android. Something like a 0 or 1 value indicating whether all the data is sent or not. So when we view our own telemetry then we know whether we have sent all the data or not. Or we could actually add a number indicating how many errors were either sent or kept on hold. I think the former is better i.e. it is probably sufficient to know whether all was sent or not and tell us to look at additional rows in the PerRequestTable. I don't see much value from knowing exactly how much was sent or not. What do you think @kreedula ?
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText: I think sending a boolean (0 or 1) to indicate if the data is partial or complete would be helpful .My primary concern raising this is , potentially in future we might end up sending partial data for every request and keep on accumulating old data , thus latest data could be lagging. Atleast having this information will help us to investigate and we probably can increase the payload if needed.
replies.author: kreedula

replies.bodyText: Addressed
replies.author: shahzaibj

timeline.bodyText: nit : final here and everywhere else in the method for local variables
timeline.author: kreedula

replies.bodyText: Addressed
replies.author: shahzaibj

timeline.bodyText: When would we disable this telemetry? If this method is only to check if we have telemetry or not, we might to have rename this method more appropriately
timeline.author: kreedula

replies.bodyText: It is disabled in the sense disabled for a command such as the GetDeviceModeCommand that returns false for isEligibleForEstsTelemetry, but I agree this can be renamed to something better. Perhaps isCurrentTelemetryAvailable or isTelemetryCaptured?
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText: Yup, isCurrentTelemetryAvailable seems better to me
replies.author: kreedula

replies.bodyText: I'd suggest using 'eligible' instead of 'avaiable' - so that we know it came from isEligibleForEstsTelemetry
replies.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: That may not be necessarily true. If we refactor the code in the future and introduce a bug then we may not have telemetry due to a bug and not simply because a command wasn't eligible.
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText: Addressed
replies.author: shahzaibj

timeline.bodyText: nit: is this private function being used elsewhere? (as in, why is it separated from the other emit with 2 params).
timeline.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: No it is not being elsewhere
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText: I can remove it and move the logic to the two param method
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText: Addressed
replies.author: shahzaibj

timeline.bodyText: Why are we duplicating the data?
timeline.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: duplicating?
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText: The data there needs to be on both current request and last request telemetry objects. derive is just a helper method to grab all the common platform fields easily without explicitly calling emit for each one.
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText:
It was sort of confusing to me to have the same telemetry object in both fields (current and last).
I would expect us to only send 'previous failing requests' in this 'Last request' fields. Isn't that the case?
(If this particular request is not sent and it failed, only then we added it to the cache, and the next request would pick it up and send it to the server).
replies.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText:
Yes, that's right, we only send previous failing requests/errors. However, we also have to abide by the schema and send all fields/delimiters regardless of whether they have value or not. So it there are no last request telemetry available in the cache, then we need to send something like this:
2|0|||
i.e. We still send the schema version all delimiters
replies.author: shahzaibj

timeline.bodyText: is this thread safe? (Since we support parallel request)
timeline.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: Yes, we are using concurrent data structures.
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText: What I meant was... is it technically possible for any two concurrent requests to send the same set of 'failed_requests' or 'errors'. If so, would the server side be able to deal with it.
replies.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: Yes, it is possible, and the server won't do anything. It means that we would have duplicated data there.
replies.author: shahzaibj

timeline.bodyText:
I think it might be risky using index as we're supporting concurrent requests.
What if we have the command store a list of last request correlation ID, and if sent, then we remove the entry with the associated correlation ID from the cache?
timeline.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: It is basically separation of concerns. I don't fully understand what you're suggesting but right now the data is stored in the SharedPreferences and persists. Are you suggesting to store in the Command? Commands are temporary so once those are over we would lose information.
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText:
Let's say if we have more than 1 command running at the same time, and then they get the same value from getLoggedTelemetryIndex() and then try to wipe at the same time, would index out of bound occur?
I was suggesting storing the 'key' of failed request/error cache entry inside command, and then use those keys to wipe the values out. This would make it thread-safe. (the first wipe will win, the later wipes will not do anything).
replies.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: or there might be another way to address this. My concern is primarily the OutOfBound exception.
replies.author: rpdome
shahzaibj

replies.bodyText:
ahh.. ok. so you wipe from each instance then proceed to save those instances to the cache, and in this case the last one wins.
Ok in this case we should be safe from OOB. I'm still in the middle of PR and thought that you saved those request/error entries separately.
replies.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText:
The potential error that could happen in this case is a missing telemetry (i.e. There are 5 concurrent requests, the 3rd request failed, but the 5th overwrites the lastRequestTelemetry object).
Which could potentially be solved if saveRequestTelemetryToCache actually 'merges' the request. Not sure if the code would be straightforward/easy to understand though.
replies.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: Having each command keeping track of what 'last request/error' it sent might be more straightforward IMHO. In this case, we can be certain we only wipe the ones that are already sent.
replies.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: @rpdome I've taken your suggestion and refactored the code. I didn't do at the command though as I believe telemetry should be kept separate from commands as much as possible due to separation of concerns. Also the currently executing command isn't available from everywhere. We would have to put the entire command object on the DiagnosticContext if we are to achieve that. I want to avoid doing that. So to solve this problem I've create a new Set at the telemetry layer that keeps track of all the failed requests sent to the server for the currently executing request and then later when we flush, we just remove all of these from the cache as these are sent. Two FailedRequest objects are considered the same if they have the same correlationId so I'm using that as you suggested to keep track of this. The index is no longer used and I've removed that. Thanks for the suggestion!
replies.author: shahzaibj

timeline.bodyText: Shouldn't this value be part of the lastRequestTelemetry object (like the associated failedRequest/error arrays).
timeline.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: No, this value isn't actually part of telemetry i.e. it isn't actually a field in the schema and hence I didn't add it LastRequest Telemetry class.
replies.author: shahzaibj

timeline.bodyText:
I suggest keeping a separate copy of this inside the last request object (as same as the arrays).
Like other values, the telemetry cache should be modified in only one place - flush().
timeline.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: This field has been removed now per your suggestion.
replies.author: shahzaibj

timeline.bodyText:
nit: the term 'derive', along with the comment above, gave me an impression that we're actually copying everything from CurrentRequestTelemetry.
Should we rename this to something along the line of 'copySharedValues'?
timeline.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: Addressed
replies.author: shahzaibj

timeline.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: No, I added them initially because I planned to use them but didn't. We may need these when we implement future schema versions, but I can remove it for now.
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText: Addressed
replies.author: shahzaibj

timeline.message:
Address more comments

Move away from Index to keep track of how many failed requests were sent to server, instead keep track based on Set of failed request sent and remove those when sent

timeline.bodyText:
How would this work for parallel commands?
Each of them will have their own copies,  how are we going to resolve the conflict? As of now I believe the last one wins (which would result in missing telemetries, if any of the concurrent commands failed).
timeline.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: If it happens at exactly the same time then yes some data will get overriden and some telemetry may go missing. Do you think I should make this method synchronized?
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText:
If we want to make it synchronized, then we have to make flush() synchronized - one has to save before the other loads.
alternatively, we could save the 'changes' instead of the whole request telemetry object. (i.e. delete A, add B).
replies.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText: I was thinking about making both flush and getTelemetryHeaders synchorized. What do you think about that?
replies.author: shahzaibj

replies.bodyText:
That would be simpler to implement, but probably be a bottleneck if there are multiple requests.... so.. tradeoffs here.
This probably depends on the number of parallel requests we're expecting - especially in Broker.
I personally prefer #2, but if you think it's too complicated (to maintain) and not worth the performance gain, then I'm also fine with #1 as well. I'll let you make the call.
replies.author: rpdome

replies.bodyText:
Yeah I think 2 would be complicated to maintain and not worth the effort/performance gain.
I went ahead using the 1st approach and addressed it here: c05a810
replies.author: shahzaibj
